content.question: Let <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the function defined by <math alttext="f of x, equals, the fraction with numerator 2 plus cosine x, and denominator x squared, end fraction" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>. The derivative of <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="f prime of x, equals, the negative of the fraction with numerator x squared times sine x, plus 2 x, times, open parenthesis, 2 plus cosine x, close parenthesis, and denominator x to the fourth power, end fraction" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. The graph of the function <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> defined by <math alttext="g of x, equals, x squared times sine x, plus 2 x, times, open parenthesis, 2 plus cosine x, close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown above for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 100" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Let <math alttext="b sub n, equal, f of n" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> for all integers <math alttext="n greater than or equal to 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>≥</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the following statements about the series <math alttext="the sum, from n equals 1, to infinity, of, open parenthesis, negative 1, close parenthesis, raised to the n plus 1 power, times b sub n" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><munderover><mo>∑</mo><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>∞</mi></mrow></munderover><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><msub><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></math> is true?

choices.label: The series converges by the alternating series test.
The alternating series test cannot be used to determine convergence because the series is not alternating.

The alternating series test cannot be used to determine convergence because <math alttext="the limit as n approaches infinity, of b sub n, is not equal to 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>∞</mi></mrow></munder><msub><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo>≠</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The alternating series test cannot be used to determine convergence because the terms <math alttext="b sub n" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> are not decreasing.

content.answer: The alternating series test cannot be used to determine convergence because the terms <math alttext="b sub n" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> are not decreasing.
